comments.content:
Correct: Marketing: Guest Access
Reason: Guest Access is specifically designed for collaboration with external users on specific teams and channels within your organization. It allows them to access files, participate in chats, and join meetings within the designated team or channel. This aligns perfectly with the marketing department's need to collaborate on a PowerPoint presentation in a team's General channel.
IT: External Access
Reason: External Access enables communication with external users via chat and calls, but without granting access to teams or channels. This suits the IT department's requirement for private chats and calls with external consultants without sharing internal team resources.
Explanation of why other options aren't suitable:
B2B Direct Connect: This feature is primarily for federating with other Azure AD organizations, allowing seamless collaboration between trusted partners. It's not ideal for one-off external consultant interactions as in this scenario.

discussion.content: I think the correct answer is 30 days and MS Teams admin center

You have 30 days to restore a deleted team. After 30 days, the team and its associated data are permanently deleted and cannot be recovered.

Microsoft 365 admin center to restore the deleted team.
Steps to Restore the Team:
Go to the Microsoft 365 admin center.
Navigate to Groups > Deleted groups.
Find and select the team (group) you want to restore.
Click on Restore group.

Team Admin Centre to restore the deleted team.
Steps :-
Go to teams admin center
Navigate to Teams > Managed Teams
On the Top-Right side of page click on the ACTION tab > View Deleted Teams
Find and select the team (group) you want to restore.
Click on Restore Team.
This will restore team as well as the group

(Both method tested)
Therefor, Portal: - 365 admin center as well as team admin center

Restore deleted teams
To restore a deleted team in the Teams admin center, do the following:
Go to the Teams Admin center > Teams > Manage teams.
Expand Actions menu on the top right corner, click View deleted teams.
Select the team that you want to restore from the list, and then click Restore. You can also select multiple teams and restore them.

Source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/manage-teams-in-modern-portal

Timeframe for Restoration:

You have 30 days to restore a deleted team. After 30 days, the team and its associated data are permanently deleted and cannot be recovered.
Portal to Use:

You should use the Microsoft 365 admin center to restore the deleted team.
Steps to Restore the Team:

 Go to the Microsoft 365 admin center.
 Navigate to Groups > Deleted groups.
 Find and select the team (group) you want to restore.
 Click on Restore group.

By following these steps within the 30-day window, you can restore the deleted team and recover its associated data.

The MS 365 Admin Center
If you're a global administrator or a groups administrator, you can restore a deleted group in the Microsoft 365 admin center:

Go to the Microsoft 365 admin center.
Expand Groups, and then select Deleted groups.
Select the group that you want to restore, and then select Restore group.

NO-YES-YES
User1 can switch to the public preview features by using the Teams client: NO

Explanation: User1's policy (Policy1) explicitly disables public preview features, overriding the Global policy's "Follow office preview" setting. Therefore, User1 cannot access public preview features, even though the Global policy would usually allow it.
User2 can switch to the public preview features by using the Teams client: YES

Explanation: User2's policy (Policy2) explicitly enables public preview features, overriding the Global policy. This allows User2 to access public preview features within their Teams client, regardless of the Office preview schedule.
User3 can switch to the public preview features by using the Teams client: YES

Explanation: User3 falls under the Global policy, which permits users to manually toggle public preview features, making them accessible.
